title: Taehwan (Jack) Kim
text: Greetings! I’m Jack. Junior and Economics major at Pomona College. Formerly of Class of 2024, finally back at school after serving in the Republic of Korea Army Special Forces. My interest lies in the world of finance and value investing. Love to play soccer (lifelong Arsenal fan) and love to share my military endeavors.

title: Case Analysis 2: Premier League 2021-2022
text:
TidyTuesday Reference
Original Data Source
Objective of the Analysis: Which referee gave out the most yellow cards to Arsenal during the 2021-2022 season?
Refereeing decisions play huge outcome in a football match. In fact, fans and analysts alike do pay enormous attention to the designated referee for each fixture. As a lifelong Arsenal fan, I wanted to find out which referees tend to be harsher on Arsenal.









The bar chart represents the total number of yellow cards each referee has given to Arsenal. Craig Pawson handed out the most yellow cards to Arsenal, with 9 cards given.

title: Case Analysis 1: Olympics
text:
TidyTuesday Reference
Original Data Source
Objective: Usually it is the Olympic athletes that receive the fame. However, at the end of the day they each represent their country with pride. Let’s find out which nations are represented the most in the top 10 most successful athlete list (measured by medal count). So, which countries have produced the best talents?


# A tibble: 10 × 3
   name                                                team         total_medals
   <chr>                                               <chr>               <int>
 1 "Michael Fred Phelps, II"                           United Stat…           28
 2 "Larysa Semenivna Latynina (Diriy-)"                Soviet Union           18
 3 "Nikolay Yefimovich Andrianov"                      Soviet Union           15
 4 "Borys Anfiyanovych Shakhlin"                       Soviet Union           13
 5 "Edoardo Mangiarotti"                               Italy                  13
 6 "Ole Einar Bjrndalen"                               Norway                 13
 7 "Takashi Ono"                                       Japan                  13
 8 "Aleksey Yuryevich Nemov"                           Russia                 12
 9 "Dara Grace Torres (-Hoffman, -Minas)"              United Stat…           12
10 "Jennifer Elisabeth \"Jenny\" Thompson (-Cumpelik)" United Stat…           12


# A tibble: 6 × 2
  team          count
  <chr>         <int>
1 Soviet Union      3
2 United States     3
3 Italy             1
4 Japan             1
5 Norway            1
6 Russia            1











USSR and United States produced the highest number of most successful athletes. Russia (formerly USSR) and the US usually rank top 3 for medal counts. It is actually surprising to find China not represented in the list.
As for most successful athletes, Michael Phelps is by far has won the most medals (28).

title: Case Analysis 3: Netflix Movies
text:
TidyTuesday Reference
Original Data Source
This dataset consists of tv shows and movies available on Netflix as of 2019. The dataset is collected from Flixable which is a third-party Netflix search engine.
In 2018, they released an interesting report which shows that the number of TV shows on Netflix has nearly tripled since 2010. The streaming service’s number of movies has decreased by more than 2,000 titles since 2010, while its number of TV shows has nearly tripled. It will be interesting to explore what all other insights can be obtained from the same dataset.
Integrating this dataset with other external datasets such as IMDB ratings, rotten tomatoes can also provide many interesting findings.

# Get the Data

# Read in with tidytuesdayR package 
# Install from CRAN via: install.packages("tidytuesdayR")
# This loads the readme and all the datasets for the week of interest

# Either ISO-8601 date or year/week works!

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2021-04-20')
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2021, week = 17)

netflix <- tuesdata$netflix

library(tidyverse)


Who are the actors with the most movie appearances? Let’s find the top 5 actors by the number of appearances.


actor_count <- netflix |>
  filter(type == "Movie", !is.na(cast)) |> 
  separate_rows(cast, sep = ",\\s*") |> 
  count(cast, sort = TRUE)

top_5_actors <- actor_count |>
  slice_head(n = 5) 


ggplot(top_5_actors, aes(x = reorder(cast, n), y = n)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    title = "Top 5 Actors Appearing in Netflix Titles",
    x = "Actor",
    y = "Number of Appearances"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() 








Interesting, I actually do not know any of these actors/actresses. Upon some research, I have found that all of them are Indian actors/actresses.
Just out of curiosity, let’s find out which countries produced the most number of movies?

country_count_movies <- netflix |>
  filter(type == "Movie", !is.na(country)) |>  
  separate_rows(country, sep = ",\\s*") |>  
  count(country, sort = TRUE)  

top_5_countries <- country_count_movies |>
  slice_head(n = 5)  


ggplot(top_5_countries, aes(x = reorder(country, n), y = n)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    title = "Top 5 Countries Producing the Most Netflix Movies",
    x = "Country",
    y = "Number of Movies"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Unsurprisingly, the US has produced the most Netflix movies.This makes sense given that Hollywood is the global hub of film production. With the growing size of Bollywood, India comes in for second place.

Most popular words in movie titles:

We have excluded articles, pronouns, prepositions and any common stop words.

# A list of words we want to exclude
stop_words <- c("a", "an", "the", "and", "in", "on", "of", "with", "for", "to", "he", "she", "my", "it", "him", "her", "above", "below", "top", "bottom", "between", "front", "back", "beneath", "they", "me", "you", "them", "us", "we", "that", "this", "these", "those", "I", "from", "i", "at", "")

word_count <- netflix |>
  filter(type == "Movie", !is.na(title)) |>
  mutate(clean_title = str_remove_all(title, "[^A-Za-z\\s]")) |>
  mutate(clean_title = str_to_lower(clean_title)) |>
  separate_rows(clean_title, sep = "\\s+") |> 
  filter(!clean_title %in% stop_words) |> 
  count(clean_title, sort = TRUE) 

head(word_count, 10)

# A tibble: 10 × 2
   clean_title     n
   <chr>       <int>
 1 love           91
 2 christmas      72
 3 movie          60
 4 man            58
 5 story          54
 6 life           44
 7 world          42
 8 little         39
 9 live           38
10 one            38


Love and Christmas are the top two most common words. These results do makes sense as these are pretty popular topics.

The most commercially successful filmmaker in the history of Hollywood is Steven Spielburg. Let’s figure out which of his movies are on Netflix.


spielberg_movies <- netflix |>
  filter(type == "Movie", str_detect(director, "Steven Spielberg"))

head(spielberg_movies$title)

[1] "Catch Me If You Can"                               
[2] "Hook"                                              
[3] "Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull"
[4] "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade"                
[5] "Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark"     
[6] "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom"              


Surprising, only 6 are available on Netflix. Given sheer amount of Spielberg movies we know of, this a very small number.

Following Covid-19, less people are going to the movies. At the same time over-the-top streaming services have become more influential. Nowadays, people are wondering “when is my favorite movie going to be on Netflix?”. So let’s find out, on average, how long does it take for a movie to be added on Netflix.

Two caveats: - We have exact dates for the when the movie was added, but only the year data is available for when it was released. Hence, we will just find the number of years. - Netflix started streaming services in 2007. Any movie produced before 2007 will be excluded because that just automatically increases the average.

netflix <- netflix |>
  mutate(
    date_added = mdy(date_added),  
    release_year = as.numeric(release_year)  
  )

netflix <- netflix |>
  mutate(added_year = year(date_added))  

netflix <- netflix |>
  mutate(time_diff_years = added_year - release_year)  

netflix_era <- netflix |>
  filter(!is.na(time_diff_years) & time_diff_years >= 0 & release_year >= 2007) 

average_time_diff <- netflix_era |>
  summarize(average_diff = mean(time_diff_years, na.rm = TRUE))

average_time_diff

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  average_diff
         <dbl>
1         2.14


On average, it takes 2.14 years for a movie to be added on Netflix after being released in the theaters.

title: Project_2
text:
TidyTuesday Reference
Original Data Source

  count(clean_title, sort = TRUE) 

head(word_count, 10)

# A tibble: 10 × 2
   clean_title     n
   <chr>       <int>
 1 love           91
 2 christmas      72
 3 movie          60
 4 man            58
 5 story          54
 6 life           44
 7 world          42
 8 little         39
 9 live           38
10 one            38


Love and Christmas are the top two most common words. These results do makes sense as these are pretty popular topics.

[1] "Catch Me If You Can"

average_time_diff

# A tibble: 1 × 1

         <dbl>
1         2.14
